This resembles the former, iu that two or more creditors (correi stipulandi or credendi) are entitled against one debtor, or two or more debtors (correi promittendi or debendi) are bound to one creditor in respect of one and the same obligation-obJect, and so far we may say that every correal includes in itself a solidary obligation‚ each of the two or more creditors being entitled, and each of the two or more debtors being bound, in solidum. But it differs in that there is not only one obligation·object, but only one obligation. The unity of the object here follows necessarily from the unity of the obligation itself : where the liability is solidary, it arises from extraneous causes, for, given a variety of obligatione, the natural and usual consequence would be a corresponding variety of objects.

It is thus the unity or identity of the obligation which distinguishes correal from merely solidary obligation: or, to put the matter in another form, when there is correality‚ there is, objectively, one single obligation, to which a variety of persons are subjectively related in solidum: and their subjective relation may be different.

There is, objectively‚ but oue single obligation.
